title.justification: This is the title of the paper.

extractions.description: The paper introduces a distributionally robust contextual optimization model aimed at maximizing the coefficient of prescriptiveness, a measure that compares the quality of contextual decisions against a reference decision. The model incorporates side information and addresses distribution shifts. Additionally, a bisection algorithm for solving the model is presented and evaluated through numerical experiments on a contextual shortest path problem.

type.justification: The paper conducts numerical experiments to evaluate the robustness of the proposed model against benchmark methods, making it an empirical study.
type.quote: Studying a contextual shortest path problem, we evaluate the robustness of the resulting policies against alternative methods when the out-of-sample dataset is subject to varying amounts of distribution shift.

name.justification: This paper focuses on optimization techniques, specifically distributionally robust contextual optimization models.
name.quote: This paper introduces a distributionally robust contextual optimization model where the coefficient of prescriptiveness substitutes for the classical empirical risk minimization objective.

name.justification: The paper deals with optimization under uncertainty using stochastic programming and robust optimization techniques.
name.quote: Stochastic programming is perceived as one of the fundamental methods devised for decision-making under uncertainty (see Shapiro et al. (2021) and Birge and Louveaux (2011)).

name.justification: The paper aims to enhance decision-making by leveraging contextual data, a key aspect of prescriptive analytics.
name.quote: This paradigm encourages decision-makers to benefit from the available data beyond the desired random variables to make more anticipative decisions.
